lyrics.lyrics: It's in the trees
It's coming
When I was a child, running in the night
Afraid of what might be
Hiding in the dark, hiding in the street
And of what was following me
The hounds of love are hunting
I've always been a coward
And I don't know what's good for me
Oh, here I go
It's coming for me through the trees
Oh, help me, someone
Help me, please
Take my shoes off
And throw them in the lake
And I'll be two steps on the water
I found a fox caught by dogs
He let me take him in my hands
His little heart, it beats so fast
And I'm ashamed of running away
From nothing real
I just can't deal with this
I'm still afraid to be there
Among the hounds of love
And feel your arms surround me
I've always been a coward
And never know what's good for me
Oh, here I go, don't let me go
Hold me down
It's coming for me through the trees
Oh, help me, darling
Help me, please
Take my shoes off
And throw them in the lake
And I'll be two steps on the water
I don't know what's good for me
I don't know what's good for me
I need love, love, love, love, love, yeah
Your love
And take your shoes off
And throw them in the lake
Do you know what I really need?
Do you know what I really need?
Love, love, love, love, love, yeah

lyricsAnnotations.lyrics:
From nothing real, I just can’t deal with this
 I’m still afraid to be there
annotation:
She doesn’t believe in “love”. It appears that she finds it as a distraction and a chore, instead of a real emotion as she’s never felt it and never wants to. It could link to a fear of the vulnerability love imposes being used against her, and due to her inexperience she wouldn’t notice it. She may feel ashamed of the fact she is so afraid and opposed to a feeling, as it is not a physical threat, yet she may still feel as though she is prey being chased by a predator and would rather be safe than sorry, not willing to let any guard down.
She may have unconscious fears of things such as abandonment and betrayal, which prevent her from any reciprocation of love. It could have stemmed from a past relationship, or as I believe is more likely here, a fear of how overwhelming it seems to be to love and be loved and eventually lose.

lyricsAnnotations.lyrics:
When I was a child, running in the night
 Afraid of what might be
 Hiding in the dark, hiding in the street
 And of what was following me
annotation:
Love seems to be a predicament that she’s never been certain of and always had a fear of since she was a child. She knew she felt something, but there was possibly a sign of it being something other than love. Fear and love are very similar: heart racing, dizziness, fatigue, obsession – so if learnt young, the emotion of love could be extremely distorted. As a result, she feels it is too great of a risk to test the emotion (whether it is love or not), as it poses a risk of her being deceived.
Children have little sense of the real world, and would rather be carefree than have to live with constant fear and worry of which comes with maturity as we age older. There is definitely an issue in her eyes (possibly due to the environment around her), alike how a child may be unable to fully comprehend issues yet know they are negative.
It could symbolise the fact that love isn’t something she’s at all familiar with, and therefore wants to escape it before it can develop to something worse before it becomes a habit.

lyricsAnnotations.lyrics:
Oh, here I go
 It’s coming for me through the trees
annotation: As this sentiment is repeated throughout the song, it begins to take on a different tone. At first it sounds as though the singer wants to escape, but it becomes clear that the fear and anxiety is mixed with desire and anticipation.

lyricsAnnotations.lyrics:
I don’t know what’s good for me
 I don’t know what’s good for me
 I need love, love, love, love, love, yeah
 Yeah-yo, yeah-yo, your love
annotation: The singer doesn’t trust her own instincts, and is placing her faith in the man she’s met instead.

lyricsAnnotations.lyrics:
Oh, here I go, don’t let me go
 Hold me down
 It’s coming for me through the trees
annotation: It’s coming for her, but she wants him to hold her down and not let her go, so she can’t escape, because she doesn’t want her fear to get in the way. “Hold me down” is possibly a double entendre.

lyricsAnnotations.lyrics:
I found a fox caught by dogs
 He let me take him in my hands
 His little heart, it beat so fast
 And I’m ashamed of running away
annotation:
By comparing herself to the saviour of a small, vulnerable creature, she explains that she feels as if she’s her partner’s source of emotional support – cradling him.

She can’t bear to leave because she knows that her partner is too vulnerable to be left on his own.

Alternatively, Kate might be finding the plight of someone/something else to dwarf her own fear, which makes her feel bad for (over)reacting and being cowardly when she has the power to comfort.

lyricsAnnotations.lyrics:
Take my shoes off and throw them in the lake
 And I’ll be
 Two steps on the water
annotation:
The use of water imagery suggests Kate is ready to take the plunge and enter a relationship.

Kate talks about her reasons for using “two steps”, saying:

Two steps is a progression. One step could possibly mean you go forward and then you come back again. I think “two steps” suggests that you intend to go forward.

(Source: Gaffaweb)

lyricsAnnotations.lyrics: Oh, help me, darling, help me, please
annotation:
Contrasting with previous lines in this song, Kate now directly asks her lover for help. In taking the risk of falling in love she’s gained someone she can trust and finds sanctuary in them.

The fact that Kate has found someone to look after her detracts some of the terror from the song, overcoming the initial fear of falling in love and putting your trust in someone.

lyricsAnnotations.lyrics: Oh, help me, someone, help me, please
annotation:
“Hounds of Love” has been compared to Kate’s iconic “Running Up That Hill” for its similar use of vocal to portray a sense of hysteria.

In “Hounds of Love” there’s an energy of despair, yes. It’s about someone terrified, who is searching for a way to escape something. My voice, and the entire production, are directed towards the expression of that terror.

(Source: Gaffaweb)

Kate sings these lines with a raw emotion. She presents herself as isolated and desperate, seemingly pleading to the listener to reach out and save her from her fears.

lyricsAnnotations.lyrics: It’s in the trees, it’s coming!
annotation:
In a 1992 Radio 1 interview with Richard Skinner, Bush explained this intro:

[‘Hounds of Love’] was inspired in some ways by this old black and white movie that is a real favorite of ours, called Night of the Demon. It’s all about this demon that appears in the trees. And the line at the top of the song, ‘It’s in the trees—It’s coming!’, is actually taken from the film. Maurice Denham is the guy that sang it.

As Bush herself says, these lines are from 1957 horror film Night of the Demon. Starring actor Maurice Denham speaks them.

sections.explanation: The introduction and initial verse, exploring themes of fear and childhood.
The chorus, expressing the hounds of love and the protagonist's fear and avoidance.
The second verse, diving deeper into the metaphor of the hounds and the protagonist's fear.
The bridge, introducing new imagery and connecting the themes of fear and desire.
The climax and repetition of the chorus, building up emotion and intensity.
The outro, closing with the theme of desire and resignation.

song_start.explanation: The song starts with a haunting atmosphere, setting up the theme of fear and anticipation.

song_end.explanation: The song ends with a blend of longing and peace, completing the emotional journey.
